This is the quintessential "so bad it's good" movie. The first thing you need to know about Troll 2, to adjust your expectations, is that it contains not a single troll. If that seems like a pretty big problem for a film called Troll 2, then you haven't seen anything yet. This movie contains such fantastical scenes as... as... a helpful ghost stopping time so that a kid can jump onto a dinner table and pee all over his family's food, which is naturally the only sane way to prevent them from eating a substance that would otherwise turn them all into goblin snacks (oh, yes, there are goblins in Troll 2, just no trolls). In another scene, the villainous witch who rules the goblins becomes a sexy femme fatale and seduces a young man in his trailer, brandishing what I can only describe as a corn-on-the-cob dildo. After the lad falls under the witch's spell, so to speak, the two frolic on his bed "eating" the phallic corn until, at the climactic moment, popcorn erupts out of thin air, shooting everywhere and covering them. This is some pretty strong visual allegory for a PG 13 rated release! The narrative purpose of the scene, though, like much in Troll 2, is unclear, given that after the witch leaves the lad he seems perfectly fine and none the worse for his experience. Others victims are not so lucky, finding themselves turned into edible vegetation for goblins to feast upon. Some of the acting in Troll 2 vies with the best that Tommy Wiseau's The Room or Neil Breen's Fateful Findings has to offer. I would say that Troll 2 is unintentionally hilarious, but I'm not so confident in offering an opinion on what the filmmakers intended when making Troll 2. What I can say is that, although Troll 2 is "bad" on a whole different level from most of its competitors, I unironically love it.

First and foremost it foretold the vegetarian and vegan revolution that would eventually sweep the nation. It was a warning we now wish we had heeded. I fear for my children being attacked by little anti-meat goblins and keep bologna readily available in my home. And who could have predicted the rise of "The Devil's Drink".....coffee. The residents of Nilbog wouldn't have imagined how addicted to Starbucks we've become.
Secondly, the personality of George Hardy was introduced to the world. This important event in cinema lore has to be witnessed. I can't explain it in a movie review. Suffice it to say his scene carrying little Joshua through the house rhapsodizing the merits of hospitality has to be viewed over and over. It's that good. 
Also the brilliance of Troll 2, and this can't be overstated, is the irrelevance of a film's title. I finally understand that you can call a movie whatever you want and still create a masterpiece. I am thinking of making a movie about cyborgs taking over a tractor pull and monster truck rally before infiltrating Washington politics and calling it The Many Loves Of Allison. Or Possibly a love story at a nursing home where aliens leave pods that cause the elderly to become young again and call it DIABEETUS 3. The Title doesn't matter. It's the story that will draw in an audience. But whatever I or anyone else creates in the world of cinema it probably won't achieve the mind-blowing brilliance of Troll 2.

So this is about a family that goes on a vacation for the month to Nilbog, participating in some household exchange program (...?), only to find all of the inhabitants of the town are all goblins in disguise, trying to trick them into eating vegetables so as to turn them into half-plants in order to eat them.  I finally took the time to watch one of the most infamously bad movies ever made, and let me tell you, I had a great time.  Don't be put off with how I am rating it, as I am grading it purely from a filmmaking standpoint; it is unintentionally hilarious to the core.  The thing about making a good bad movie is that you can't set out to make a bad movie; if you wink too hard at your audience, the joke ceases to be funny, and then you end up with something like Machete.  You have to have a madman sitting in the director's chair and let it happen naturally, and that's how you wind up with something like Troll 2 or The Room.  Everything about this is fun if you watch it in the right atmosphere, from the clunky exposition to the wooden performances, from the laugh-worthy troll masks and make-up to the drunkenly penned dialogue, there is nothing here that doesn't fail hard.  This is the type of movie that the more people you watch it with, the better, and it ends up being a create-your-own MST3K.

Rivaling Tommy Wiseau's "The Room" for the best unintentional comedy ever comes Troll 2, a horrendously inept trainwreck of a movie that is as fascinating as it is bad. There's really not much that I can say that hasn't been said already, but here's a start:

The acting isn't nearly as consistently bad as The Room's, but certain key moments stand out when they become a spectacle of hilarity (see: "They're eating her...and now they're going to eat me! OH MY GOOOOOOOOOD!"). The storytelling is tremendously weak, and showcases tremendously obvious foreshadowing that any sane person could see. The writing is just plain awful, featuring lines such as "Nilgob! It's goblin spelled backwards!" and the immortal "You can't piss on hospitality!" And the plot? Oh yeah, don't even get me started. This is a movie about goblins (despite being called Troll 2) that feed people food that makes them sweat/bleed chlorophyll and turns them into half-plant, half-human hybrids, "the goblins' favorite food". Yeah. Not even joking. 

What does elevate this movie to "so-bad-it's-good" status are any of the scenes that involve Grandpa Seth or the dad, played by Robery Ormsby and George Hardy, respectively. It's never really explained if Grandpa Seth is a figment of the kids imagination or not, and that just adds to the comedic factor in the movie. Also noteworthy is the horrifyingly creepy shopkeeper, who, if you've watched the documentary based on this film, "Best Worst Movie", was actually in a mental institution at the time of filming. Explains quite a bit.

If there's one person to blame for the astoundingly bad quality of this film, it's Italian director Claudio Fragrasso. If you look up some of the backstory to this film, you'll learn that he thought he knew more about American teenagers than the actual cast and crew, and also thought that he was pretty much the best director of all time. It's pretty clear that he had no clue what he was doing or what constitutes a good movie. 

Though Troll 2 isn't nearly as hilariously bad as other unintentional comedies (see: The Room), you can find a lot to have fun with in this movie, even if sometimes it is just boring. I personally didn't think that this film was as notoriously bad as its reputation suggests, but there's still a lot to enjoy when watching Troll 2.
